192.desc: CSG TCG ( Delivery - Technical Consulting )  Average career for "top tech"
192.pros: Secure, high demand if you're remotely technically capable. Sales team keeps selling and customers keep buying.Very inclusive, everyone tries to be nice.
192.cons: Platform is below average. Compensation below average. Pay is mid market but if you stay you will fall behind - there's a running internal joke that you have to leave and come back to get ahead - Boomeranging...RSUs are weak , you are also limited in trading windows and CEO keeps doing dog acquisitions that tank the stock when your window opens. ( e.g. within days of slack acquisition announcement stock went 320-240. Then the trading window opened. Stock still hasn't recovered, thanks Mark. )Technical capability of delivery team on average and most customers is below average. Work is generally pretty mundane.Bringing in artists, teachers and whoever and making them technical consultants is very inclusive, but makes it challenging to have high performing teams overall. If you're senior you will spend a ton of time training your own teams on the job.Specific skills not that transferable to wider market. Apex is quirky and old, LWC is modern web but with an anchor around your neck. Trivial functionality is trivial, simple functionality is simple, moderately complex functionality is challenging, challenging functionality is very difficult, truly difficult functionality is really nearly impossible.Lowest common denominator customers - many poorly managed companies or IT departments make your work life awful.
192.authorInfo: Verified User Current Employee   d*****   Senior Technical Architect - Mar 22, 2022

193.desc: Great work life balance and values driven company
193.pros: Longest company I have been with. It provided me an opportunity to grow my career and develop as a leader. Salesforce is a company who do what they say. Equality and diversity is not just buzzwords but concrete, actionable initiatives were taken and are still being done to live up to this. Example is the annual fair compensation review done globally and actually adjusting comp to be competitive and ensure internal equity.
193.cons: Restrictive internal movement/promotions policy. External candidates do get a better deal. Example is not getting stocks if you move from an internal contributor into a manager role yet external candidates get this option. Limiting comp increase for internal movements
193.authorInfo: Verified User Current Employee   j****   Recruiting Manager - Mar 22, 2022

194.desc: Great WLB, very top down culture
194.pros: Overall culture is very good. WLB is very important to everyone and leadership is very supportive of PTO and volunteer time off.
194.cons: Very top down culture. Difficult to begin new initiatives (even proof of concept work) without having several lines of approval. Overall strategy/vision tends to be handwave-y.
194.authorInfo: Verified User Current Employee   u*****   Engineering Manager - Mar 22, 2022

195.pros: Salesforce on your resume turns a lot of heads and having a few years of in-house platform experience is valuable. Health benefits and unlimited PTO are decent.
195.cons: Company culture is cultish. Buying into ohana, reciting company mission statements yearly and individual KPIs divorced from actual work performance are exhausting. Individual managers may be good but management as a whole is useless. Utilization KPIs are usually out of your control and reflect badly on you if you don't over perform against a goal that's out of your hands. Employees who do move up through the company are the best at self promoting on internal company channels. Company cheerleading and having a high profile will get you much further than over performing on projects and utilization targets.Promotion cases are confrontational and there's very little real support for developing employees for future positions. Internal development tools exist but don't offer any real opportunity to develop new and advanced skill sets. Be ready to do that on your own time and budget. Pay and yearly raises are very low for the industry, 2-3% annually against consecutive multi-billion dollar quarters and best-years-ever. Best bet is to get experience, figure out what you want to do and leave for better opportunities.
195.authorInfo: Verified User Current Employee   J*****   Senior Consultant - Mar 22, 2022

346.pros: Great for building skills as a solution engineerGenerally good group of people that takes care of their ownGreat place to build a network of colleaguesGood benefitsPay is whatever it is when you join, some people get the promotions and keep moving up
346.cons: My big con is the compensation philosophy.  You join at whatever you negotiated unless you were acquired.  I was acquired and we were all put into titles that were too low for our skillset.  As a result, my group had a logjam trying to get promoted so we could all get comp increases.  Management had to make up excuses why we were not ready because they had limited budget and headcount for promotions.My understanding is that external hires come in at competitive rates with RSUs on a 4 year vesting schedule.  Only the top 5% or so of employees in the solution engineering organization below a director or senior director level receive RSUs after being hired.  The budget for pay increases is 5% on most years and there is no separate budget for promotions.  As a result, they have to rob one person to pay someone else more than 5%.  Management will make you jump through a ton of hoops for the promotion and then congratulate you with an 8% raise.Like many companies, people quit due to being underpaid and then they replace you with external hires at the OTE you got somewhere else.

A lot of my team consists of career switchers who are first getting into tech consulting. 551.desc: Great work life balance --- little focus on quality

Management knows this, but has not changed any of their practices.This is the least engineering focused I've worked at in my 20-year career. 552.pros: Good compensation, unlimited time off for higher grade employees, excellent benefits, including employee discounts.Could be okay for those near retirement if you can stomach the problems below for a while.
552.cons: Extremely top-heavy and middle to senior management is generally clueless, useless, and lacking transparency.Development is constantly pivoting in questionable directions, which seem motivated by people's appetite for career advancement rather than accomplishing strategic business goals. As a result, wasted effort is par for the course in Software Engineering.Career growth can be hindered by the (intentionally?) obscure promotion process, which lacks standards, clarity, and is really more of a popularity contest. To that end, self-promotion is shameless, rampant, and frankly annoying.The tech stack is ancient and, unlike other tech companies of its size, Salesforce really hasn't innovated anything in decades. Why should it? It relies on its deep pockets to acquire everything under the sun and its existing relationships/contracts with big and small companies alike, thanks to the competent well-connected salespeople that work here.

Comp is good if you have competing offers or if they really fight for you.I enjoy their benefits of one day off a month for mental wellness, unlimited vacation, $100/month for wellness activities or health equipment, $2.5K donation match a year, HSA, 401K aftertax, and 15% ESPP.Overall culture and excitement is present in emails and Slack and online events. It's not perfect but they are trying to keep people excited virtually. Some people say it may be trying too hard and can backfire, but I prefer this other than some old fashion company that isn't fun like Oracle, IBM, or Hewlett-Packard.

701.cons: If you are working on Salesforce core, the tech stack is pretty old. E.g. perforce, monolithic architecture, ftests that take15 minutes to run, build issues, etc; even for front end there is no React / Angular, but LWC so little of what you learn will carry over. That's why I gave career growth 4 stars. Gave management 4 stars as it was hard for some teams to have a good roadmap / ownership. And there was a lot of shuffling of teams and changing directions. 768.pros: There are some incredibly talented people here from which you can learn how to run systems at scale. Peers are generally helpful although some love to stay in their own cultural clique and the talent pool is usually among their own referrals. But in all cases, there is ample opportunities to learn — for a knowledge hungry person, this is a great company to have on the resume. Internal movements are the best! Allowances are ~okay, nothing great when compared to Silicon Valley tech companies, although the employee success group will make sure you life is a hell when you send in your receipts for reimbursement. It's a good Tier2 company to work at. Freedom of speech can be enjoyed here up to a certain extent. Just don't organize a coup here
768.cons: Good tier2 company, plummeting towards Tier3 or 4 due to unqualified middle managers, albeit too much of them. A good tech company doesn't require an infestation of managers but Salesforce thinks different. Probably why the amount of politics here have started reading their ugly head. Promotions are 99.99% biased to favorites, your talent doesn't matter. If the VP or SVP knows you then you'll climb the ladder. This is one reason good people have left Salesforce. RSU refreshers is something every competitive company gives out to retain employees but Salesforce will never give that. Again, veering towards favoritism, if you know people, you'll be handed a payment for your services. Employees Success are more like event planners and less towards the success of an employee. Very outdated tech stack and the core tech on which Salesforce is built will soon go bust because it cannot anymore work on scale. The engineering leaders are working, but not enough — they lack depth, and this goes to show that we are hiring more managers than actual engineers that knows computer stuff. Promotions are very unfair so SMTS can very well be your terminal level.
768.authorInfo: Verified User Current Employee   a*****   Software Engineer III - Sep 13, 2021

You're encouraged to move fast and speak up for yourself and your team in terms of contributions, opportunities, and scaling your work.
787.cons: It can be hard to feel heard and seen when you don't have the right people advocating for you. There are issues with nepotism and inner circles on certain teams that harbor toxic behaviors. There are many folks who get to manager rather quickly who aren't truly ready to lead people or a team because they lack compassionate perspectives. You can find yourself in a role or position without a clear next step rather easily on the wrong team. The organization still has many of the old heads around who stifle the culture's growth. 870.pros: Good pay. Way more benefits, perks, education programs, volunteering, etc than you can ever use. Nice veneer of social responsibility until you look too close. Great career stepping stone.
870.cons: If you're a UI designer, you might like it. There is no room for UX because of how the product org is run. The company overall is very sales and marketing driven. The tech division's culture is dominated by PM. PM org is incentivized to work against each other and never fix anything. They're rewarded for keeping their teams in a constant churn of vaporware for internal presentations and a shot at Dreamforce. UX is just for making my slides look good at the very last minute. Work-life balance at this company isn't for designers. You get squeezed between your PM and devs coasting. You're the only one stuck working. But none of your work will ship. UX management is too scared of losing a seat at the table with PM to ever say no to requests, no matter how unreasonable. Career progression is also a joke. Higher IC promotions have a long line. Start getting put up for your next promotion 1-2 yrs before you want it.

978.desc: Great work life balance but not great for new grads who need engineering foundation and transferrable skills
978.pros: - Work life balance - Mental health / personal life is encouraged and prioritized - Problems are on a big scale
978.cons: - Not great for young engineers. There are really smart people working there who are technically strong, but they built a lot of their technical foundation elsewhere before coming to Salesforce. Mentorship isn't really baked into it either, so you might advance through the levels, but it's nowhere near comparable to leveling up at another well known tech company. - Lots of bureaucracy and tech debt. - Not a very clear, detailed or rigorous feedback cycle. Feedback and constructive criticism is not baked into the culture. You basically only get formal feedback when you get put up for promotion. This is very different from other companies I've witnessed. - Compensation stops being competitive after new grad level. RSU's specifically only get refreshed every 3 years and this number is dropping even more.

988.desc: Poor tech infrastructure, good work/life balance
988.pros: - Great work/life balance. Tons of flexibility, no limit on PTO, overall low work hours for me.- Upper leadership has good intentions and says all the right things. The emphasis on giving back is genuine and people actually do a lot of volunteering and giving.- Jim, the CTO, gets a bad rap, but I've never seen him be anything but thoughtful and caring. I think he has made some management mistakes over the years but seems to be working through them, and there are some really good managers in the security division. He also has bold visions which sometimes get out of hand and turn into fire drills, but overall I like it - he's trying to make much needed security improvements quickly.- Some very good engineers
988.cons: - Tech infrastructure is archaic, at least 10 years out of date and 20 in some places. There is an effort to improve it but it's moving slowly. Everything moves slowly here.- Salesforce isn't really one company, it's a bunch of companies stitched together poorly, with a wide range of technical infrastructures and practices. Working across divisions is very painful despite good intentions all around.- There are a lot of mediocre engineers.- There have been a lot of mediocre and bad managers over the years in the security division. The upper managers seem to flush them out fairly quickly nowadays, but the cumulative damage is large. There is not much trust either between teams or from employees to management. - Career growth has been slow. It's unclear what's required to get promoted, and people who deserve a promo don't always get it.
988.authorInfo: Verified User Current Employee   f*****   IT Security Manager - Jun 15, 2021

1039.pros: Salesforce has incredible design leaders. They're truly great humans, compassionate and thoughtful, strong leaders, and accomplished designers to boot. The company is also very employee-centric — they provide unlimited PTO people really take, good benefits, excellent comp, and totally sane working hours (40-45 hours per week max in most normal weeks.)
1039.cons: Salesforce is sometimes too sensitive to employee needs, allowing anyone with a grievance to grind an entire team to a halt.
1039.authorInfo: Verified User Current Employee   C*****   UX Design Manager - May 27, 2021

1040.desc: Great work-life balance, but weighed down by terrible tech and limited career growth.
1040.pros: Work-life balance is great, I've never felt pressured to work overtime to make a deliverable. In general, people are mostly friendly and helpful, and there are very few assholes or tech elitists going around belittling others.
1040.cons: If you work on core, it's torture. This monolith hasn't been rearchitected since 1999 and it shows. Building and running the server is time-consuming and error-prone. The CI system is terrible and follows almost no modern best practices. Almost no tests are run before code is integrated, so unless you straight up break the build your code will probably go through, even if it breaks the most basic functionality. If you do break something, and it wasn't big enough for the entire company to notice, you probably won't find out for a couple of weeks as the test failures sit unnoticed on some obscure team's queue to be triaged. When you do break tests, 99% of the time it'll be selenium since no one seems to trust unit tests.There's absolutely no effort to improve developer productivity, so many tasks require tediously updating dozens of files, used by every team across the entire company, all of which are updated multiple times a day making delivering your code a race. Even the most commonly repeated tasks are not automated, and rarely can you even find documentation on what to do, so it's ripe for making mistakes that can take hours or even days to fix. It's not all uncommon for someone's status to be trying to fix my busted build. Since working on core is such a shitshow there's very little innovation. Many projects are incremental in nature, but the ones that aren't are always at risk for defunding since the company has chosen that it'll just acquire its future growth. This combined with near-constant reorgs makes it very difficult to grow your career since you feel like you get so little done.Engineers are rewarded for shoving shit out the door instead of delivering maintainable incremental solutions, so cowboy coders seem to rise while the more methodical engineers are left behind to clean up the mess when it inevitably breaks something for our customers.
1040.authorInfo: Verified User Current Employee   B*****   Lead Software Engineer - May 26, 2021

1113.desc: Good company to start your career with and get experience working with enterprise products.
1113.pros: Reasonable work life balance at junior positions.  Offices are very well done and offer a lot of perks when folks used to work from the offices. Opportunity to move to different teams within SF if you need a change or want to take your career in a different direction.
1113.cons: As your grow into senior roles, work life balance quickly vanishes. Senior leadership is rewarded for one and only one things -launching new products into the market. This done at the expense of work life balance for the technology organization. Very minimal growth opportunities at senior levels, promotion process is a complete black box and loaded with bias. Stock grants/refreshes are managed by VP+ only and also at their discretion.Old products are dropped in favor of new shiny products often leading to a frustrating condition with lack of ownership around a lot of products. This also leads to a constant battle with other teams to prioritize work you need them to do.

1572.desc: Expect to get forced out eventually - enjoy the honeymoon and get the F out.
1572.pros: - If you have a supportive manager, taking time off to volunteer - Good for work/life integration again if your manager is supportive - If you are an engineer, product developer, or lucky enough to land in one of the business orgs, there are great resources for training - Wellness benefit - Stock options
1572.cons: - Management and executive leadership like to reorganize on a whim, they think they are being fresh and innovative In reality, it causes nothing more than discord. It's hard to get a sense of direction when the rug is being pulled from under your feet every three months. - Expect to be end of lifed the only thing that is constant is change. Layoffs and PIPs happen all the time to really great people because of the need to make room for diversity, new ideas, and innovation. I was bluntly told by someone not to expect to retire from Salesforce. For the record, I wasn't planning on it. - People are treated as data points and resources and not looked at as a human with feelings, pressures. The only thing that matters is the bottom line.    - There is this really tired notion of Ohana meaning family. In reality, it means you have to integrate Salesforce as your identity, religious belief, social circle, family. It's like living in North Korea but with an annoyingly perky cheerleader facade.

I've been at this job five months and have already seen my department gutted for parts, a product line I was passionate about put on the chopping block, and a massive round of layoffs after our best quarter ever.The Ohana thing is complete bull, the few who do care about it are complete Kool aid drinkers and the rest of us cannot _stand_ it. And as evinced by the treatment of ICs, ohana ends at the upper management level and the rest of us have to pick up the pieces.The V2MOM exercise used for yearly planning is a complete waste of time because most of our business plans don't last a quarter, let alone a year. And yet it takes two full weeks out of my year to write this stupid document no one ever reads.I can put up with a lot of corporate bureaucratic garbage, but Salesforce is a new low in this regard.
1602.authorInfo: Verified User Current Employee   i*********   Engineer, Senior - Aug 27, 2020
